It must be about three kilometres, at a rough estimate. [j33] My best estimate of the cost would be between $10 000 and $15 000. [j33] Estimates of the total number varied between 200 and 300. b ' '[cf2]noun If someone such as a plumber or a painter gives you an estimate, they tell you roughly how much they will charge for a job.  An estimate is not binding like a quotation, but it should be fairly accurate.  [cf2]I asked for an estimate for having a gas heater fitted
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun estimation'

senses.definition: If you are estranged from your husband or wife, you do not live with him or her any more
example: <Tom's estranged from his wife. [j33] ...her estranged husband>
If you are estranged from a friend or relative, you do not see them or speak to them because you are not friendly with them any more

senses.definition: If you are estranged from your husband or wife, you do not live with him or her any more
example: <Tom's estranged from his wife. [j33] ...her estranged husband>

definition: .  for the Latin words '
example: et cetera, which mean 'and the rest'.  It is used at the end of a list of things to show that other similar things are also meant.  [cf2]Be sure to bring all the pens, pencils, erasers etc. that you'll need. [j33] She said that she was sorry I was leaving, that they'd all miss me etc., etc

senses.definition: ' If you etch something onto a material such as metal or glass, you cut into it with acid to leave a clear, lasting mark.
example: They were given a crystal vase with their initials etched on it. [j33] I bought a silver tray etched with a floral design. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you say that something is etched in your memory, you mean that you remember it clearly, usually because it is very distressing.  [cf2]The faces of the starving refugees remain etched in my mind, even after all these years
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See etching'.

definition: An etching is a picture printed from a plate that has been etched with a design

senses.definition: ' You can also call something eternal if it goes on all the time or for a long time and you are tired of it.
example: Is the universe eternal? [j33] The Antarctic is a land of eternal ice
I can't stand the kids' eternal fighting. [j33] I wish I could get rid of this eternal cold
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun eternity ' The probe was lost in space for all eternity.  I waited for an eternity.

senses.definition: ' You can also call something eternal if it goes on all the time or for a long time and you are tired of it.

I can't stand the kids' eternal fighting. [j33] I wish I could get rid of this eternal cold

definition: Ethics are the moral standards and principles that a society accepts as basic rules for behaviour.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective ethical' What she did was not entirely ethical.
example: It's against business ethics to acquire confidential information by deceit

senses.definition: ' People in Australia who belong to cultures that don't come from the British Isles are sometimes called ethnics.  This is an offensive name for them.
example: There are several different ethnic groups in Malaysia. [j33] The region has been the scene of much ethnic tension. [j33] She's an ethnic Chinese from Vietnam. 2 ' '[cf2]adjective Ethnic also refers to cultures in Australia that don't come from the British Isles.  [cf2]Do you like ethnic food? [j33] To promote equal opportunities, we must also advertise in the ethnic press
The representation of women and ethnics in business has traditionally been low

definition: Etiquette is a standard of formal, polite behaviour that is generally accepted in a particular society.
example: Western etiquette requires you to close your mouth while chewing food. [j33] I'm not sure what the etiquette is in these situations

definition: [ir(s76),(s75+6)]eucalyptus  A euca~ lyptus is a tall, ever~ green tree which is native to Australia
example: There are many differ~ ent varieties, and some of them are used for their timber and the oil in their leaves.  They are also commonly known as gum trees

definition: Euthanasia is bring~ ing about the death of a person who is suffering from a terminal illness and who wishes to die.
example: He was an enthusiastic supporter of voluntary euthanasia

definition: If people evacuate a place, they move out of it for a period of time because it would be dangerous to stay, for example because of war or a natural disaster.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun evacuation'
example: Everybody had to evacuate their homes before the floods arrived. [j33] The building had to be evacuated because of a bomb scare. [j33] Australian tourists are being evacuated from the zone

definition: If you evade something, you avoid it or escape it, often by a trick.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun evasion' Tax evasion is illegal.  Her answers were full of lies and evasions.[j35]'adjective evasive' The pilot was forced to take evasive action.  She gave an evasive answer.
example: Felix had many schemes for evading tax, but they finally caught up with him. [j33] The rat evaded capture by hiding in a hollow log. [j33] We can't evade these unpleasant truths

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5][j17][j24]v[j12]ljue[j11]t, i-' If you evaluate something, you consider it carefully to decide how good or useful it is.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun evaluation' We would welcome your evaluation of the training course.
example: Your work will be evaluated each term. [j33] The effect of the new law has not yet been evaluated. [j33] All the proposals will be evaluated and the best one chosen

senses.definition: ' You can also use evaporate to mean that something disappears, leaving nothing behind.
example: When I saw him again, my anger evaporated. [j33] I had $500 last month, but with all these bills it's just evaporated
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun evaporation'

definition: In slightly old-fashioned language, the eve of an event is the day or time immediately before it.
example: They got married on the eve of his departure. [j33] The government announced a package of tax cuts on the eve of the election. [j33] ...New Year's Eve

senses.definition: 4' even up'  If you even something up, you make it fair or equal.
example: This area isn't even enough for a tennis court. [j33] Be sure to work on an even surface. 2 ' '[cf2]adjective If something is even, it is about the same all over or all the time.  There are no big differences or changes.  [cf2]Spread the icing in an even layer. [j33] Try to hit the ball with an even, controlled movement. [j33] I'm glad to say he has a very even temper. [j33] Trim the stalks to an even length
Add a few more to this pile, to make them even. [j33] 'Do these two plates look even to you?' 'No, that one's darker
We each came top in one of the papers, so we're even. [j33] You bought the wine, so if I pay for the meal we'll be even. [j33] She vowed to get even with her rival
It should be a fairly even match
' An even number can be divided by 2, with nothing left over.  The even numbers are 2, 4, 6, 8 and so on
Even Jo dislikes her. [j33] He didn't even say thank you. [j33] I can't even boil an egg. [j33] Can't you even try to help? [j33] Even after that, he loved her
They say it'll be even hotter tomorrow. [j33] Gina's good-looking, but her sister's even more beautiful
Even if we leave now, we'll still be late. [j33] He should still be polite, even if he is your boss. [j33] I couldn't help you, even if I wanted to. [j33] Please reply, even if you can't attend
We take it in turns to buy groceries, and it all evens out in the end. [j33] Their scores evened out as the tests continued
